channel.title: NYT > Technology
channel.copyright: Copyright 2017 The New York Times Company

item.title: Uber Founder Travis Kalanick Resigns as C.E.O.
item.media:description: Travis Kalanick, the chief executive of Uber, said last week that he would take an indefinite leave of absence.
item.description: The company’s co-founder had been under increasing pressure, and several major investors demanded that he resign from the company immediately.
item.dc:creator: MIKE ISAAC

item.title: Amazon Will Let Customers Try On Clothes Before Buying
item.media:description: The chief executive of Amazon, Jeff Bezos. The retailer’s new try-on clothing service will be available only to members of Amazon Prime.
item.media:credit: Matthew Ryan Williams for The New York Times
item.description: Amazon Wardrobe, part of the Prime service and part of the company’s effort to expand in apparel, will let customers order three to 15 items of clothing without buying it.
item.dc:creator: NICK WINGFIELD

item.title: Move Over, Bitcoin. Ether Is the Digital Currency of the Moment.
item.media:description: Racks of machines at a server farm mining Bitcoins and Ether in Guizhou, China, last June.
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrié for The New York Time
item.description: Ethereum, a digital currency network that is winning over tech geeks and big companies, may soon surpass Bitcoin, its inspiration. Or it may fizzle.
item.dc:creator: NATHANIEL POPPER

item.title: Tech Titans Make Pilgrimage to White House to Discuss Government Systems
item.media:description: Tech leaders and investors, some of whom have disagreed with President Trump, met at the White House on Monday about updating government technology.
item.description: Timothy Cook, Jeff Bezos and Eric Schmidt were among 18 tech executives at a forum held by an administration they have had conflicts with.
item.dc:creator: CECILIA KANG

item.title: Critic's Notebook: When Fan Fiction and Reality Collide
item.description: The topsy-turvy power dynamics of internet culture are on display in “FANtasies,” a new fan-fiction-inspired web series.
item.dc:creator: AMANDA HESS

item.title: State of the Art: How Battling Brands Online Has Gained Urgency, and Impact
item.description: In a nation where politics have grown pitched, such campaigns suddenly feel like the most effective political action many of us can take.
item.dc:creator: FARHAD MANJOO

item.title: Toshiba Picks Preferred Bidder for Microchip Business
item.media:description: Toshiba said on Wednesday that a consortium made up of the Innovation Network Corporation of Japan, Bain Capital and the Development Bank of Japan had “presented the best proposal.”
item.description: The decision to negotiate with a Japanese-led consortium was likely to intensify a showdown with an American business partner seeking to steer the sale.
item.dc:creator: GERRY DOYLE

item.title: Germany Raids Homes of 36 People Accused of Hateful Postings Over Social Media
item.media:description: Heiko Maas, the German justice minister, is endorsing a new social media law aimed at cracking down on hate speech, a measure that an array of experts has warned is unconstitutional.
item.description: The raids were part of a coordinated campaign across 14 states. Most cases concerned politically motivated right-wing incitement, police said.
item.dc:creator: DAVID SHIMER

item.title: Bits: Daily Report: When Tech Titans Go to Washington
item.media:description: Tech leaders and investors, some of whom have disagreed with President Trump, met at the White House on Monday about updating government technology.
item.description: An event at the White House on Monday was closely watched for the Trump administration’s ability to gather leaders in the tech realm.
item.dc:creator: PUI-WING TAM

item.title: Tech Tip: What to Do When Chrome Wants to Update — but Can’t
item.description: If Google’s browser trips up trying to install a new version, check your system and settings before reinstalling the software.
item.dc:creator: J. D. BIERSDORFER

item.title: Want to Work for Jaguar Land Rover? Start Playing Phone Games
item.media:description: The Jaguar F-Pace at the New York International Auto Show in April. The carmaker said Monday that it would be recruiting 5,000 people this year, including 1,000 electronics and software engineers.
item.description: The carmaker wants potential employees to download an app with a series of puzzles it says will test for the engineering skills it hopes to bring in.
item.dc:creator: AMIE TSANG

item.title: Drones to the Rescue
item.description: Researchers find that drones carrying heart defibrillators can reach cardiac arrest victims quicker than ambulances.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Global Health: The High-Tech Device That’s Like a Bouncer for Mosquitoes
item.media:description: A mosquito trap created by Microsoft has 64 chambers that can trap individual species of mosquitoes.
item.media:credit: Michael Stravato for The New York Times
item.description: New traps that use infrared beams to identify insects are helping researchers capture more of the disease-carrying insects they need.
item.dc:creator: DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.

item.title: Tech Tip: Making Your Messages Really Move
item.description: Communicating through animated GIF files is a popular form of self-expression, and you don’t have to look far to find images to share.
item.dc:creator: J. D. BIERSDORFER

item.title: Bits: Arianna Huffington Gains Power at Uber
item.media:description: Arianna Huffington, who joined Uber’s board last year, has been gaining influence at the company.
item.description: Ms. Huffington, a founder of The Huffington Post who joined Uber’s board last year, has been helping fill a leadership void at the troubled company.
item.dc:creator: PUI-WING TAM

item.title: U.K. to Decide on 21st Century Fox Deal for Sky by June 29
item.description: Regulators handed recommendations to the country’s culture minister on whether the deal should go through.
item.dc:creator: MARK SCOTT and EMILY STEEL

item.title: Nonfiction: The iPhone Is 10 Years Old. Here’s the Story of Its Birth.
item.media:description: Apple chief executive Steve Jobs unveils the first iPhone at the Macworld Conference in January 2007.
item.description: Apple’s culture of reverence and secrecy is no match for Brian Merchant in “The One Device: The Secret History of the iPhone.”
item.dc:creator: LEV GROSSMAN
item.category: The One Device: The Secret History of the iPhone (Book)

item.title: After Terror Attacks, Britain Moves to Police the Web
item.media:description: Londoners checking their phones during lunch hour. British officials would like to create a digital backdoor to encrypted messaging technologies in hopes of detecting and preventing terrorist activity.
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.description: The country is cracking down on the use of encryption for instant messaging, as well as on potentially extremist material that circulates across social media.
item.dc:creator: MARK SCOTT

item.title: YouTube Sets New Policies to Curb Extremist Videos
item.media:description: Gatherers at a vigil for the victims of an attack on London Bridge this month. One of the attackers is said to have become radicalized by watching YouTube videos of an American Islamic preacher.
item.description: The company says it wants to quickly identify and pull down videos promoting terrorism. It will also make offensive videos harder to find.
item.dc:creator: DAISUKE WAKABAYASHI

item.title: As Uber Leaders Step Aside, Arianna Huffington’s Influence Grows
item.media:description: Arianna Huffington, left center, with Bozoma A. Saint John, Uber’s chief brand officer, in San Francisco. Ms. Huffington, a member of Uber’s board, is playing a growing role in the company as it contends with a string of scandals.
item.media:credit: Jason Henry for The New York Times
item.description: In the 14 months since she joined the board, Ms. Huffington has been a public voice for the start-up and a confidante to its chief executive.
item.dc:creator: KATIE BENNER and MIKE ISAAC

item.title: Whole Foods Deal Shows Amazon’s Prodigious Tolerance for Risk
item.media:description: Jeff Bezos, the founder of Amazon, at the Space Symposium in Colorado Springs in April. His embrace of risk and experimentation has included the development of reusable rockets.
item.media:credit: Nick Cote for The New York Times
item.description: A longtime approach of making bold — and sometimes head-scratching — moves has brought Jeff Bezos staggering success.
item.dc:creator: DAVID STREITFELD

item.title: Airbnb Tries to Behave More Like a Hotel
item.media:description: Jill Bishop, who rents out a bedroom in her Denver home, says she is dealing with the changes being asked of Airbnb’s hosts.
item.media:credit: Ryan David Brown for The New York Times
item.description: Less chatting on the couch; fewer idiosyncratic toiletries in the bath. Pursuing growth, the company promotes consistency among its millions of hosts.
item.dc:creator: KATIE BENNER

item.title: Bits: Farhad’s, Mike’s and Cade’s Week in Tech: More Uber, With a Dash of Amazon
item.media:description: Uber has announced sweeping reforms to its culture and workplace practices.
item.description: And a discussion of how Facebook is harnessing artificial intelligence — well, almost — to take on “hard questions.”
item.dc:creator: FARHAD MANJOO, MIKE ISAAC and CADE METZ

item.title: Robot Revolution: Amazon’s Move Signals End of Line for Many Cashiers
item.media:description: Shoppers in line at a Brooklyn Whole Foods. The grocery store of the future may not have checkout lines or cashiers.
item.media:credit: Nina Westervelt for The New York Times
item.description: The next jobs set to disappear may be ones that are a bigger part of people’s daily lives: retail workers and cashiers in stores and restaurants.
item.dc:creator: CLAIRE CAIN MILLER

item.title: State of the Art: In Whole Foods, Bezos Gets a Sustainably Sourced Guinea Pig
item.description: By purchasing the upscale chain, Jeff Bezos, Amazon’s chief, has a chance to tinker with how people buy groceries — and map the future of the physical store.
item.dc:creator: FARHAD MANJOO

item.title: An Online Retailer Walked Into a Salad Bar
item.media:description: All things Amazon as they add Whole Foods to their list of businesses.
item.description: Amazon announced it was buying Whole Foods, and the internet started cracking jokes.
item.dc:creator: ERIN McCANN

item.title: Bits: Daily Report: The Limits of A.I.
item.description: Facebook wants to rely on technology to help it spot extremist content. But how do you teach a computer context?
item.dc:creator: JIM KERSTETTER

item.title: Tech Tip: Claiming Your Own Little Corner of the Web
item.description: You don’t need a lot of technical expertise to make a personal site or a blog to share your thoughts with the world.
item.dc:creator: J. D. BIERSDORFER

item.title: Amazon to Buy Whole Foods for $13.4 Billion
item.media:description: Customers at a Whole Foods Market in Midtown Manhattan.
item.media:credit: John Taggart for The New York Times
item.description: The deal for a physical grocery retailer reflects Amazon’s ambition to become an even more frequent shopping habit to customers.
item.dc:creator: NICK WINGFIELD and MICHAEL J. de la MERCED

item.title: Walmart to Buy Bonobos, Men’s Wear Company, for $310 Million
item.media:description: Merchandise at the headquarters of Bonobos in New York. Walmart bought the retailer as part of its effort to compete with Amazon.
item.media:credit: John Taggart for The New York Times
item.description: Acquiring the clothing brand born on the internet is intended to energize Walmart’s e-commerce strategy as it races to catch up with Amazon.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL J. de la MERCED

item.title: Apple, Moving In on Prestige TV, Poaches Two Sony Executives
item.media:description: The actress Glenn Close with Zack Van Amburg, center, and Jamie Erlicht, the leaders of Sony Pictures Television, in 2012.
item.description: The company’s hiring of two respected leaders, who cultivated shows like “Breaking Bad” at Sony, signaled to Hollywood that Apple is serious about original programming.
item.dc:creator: BROOKS BARNES

item.title: Google Said to Be Facing Record E.U. Fine by End of August
item.media:description: Margrethe Vestager, the European Union’s antitrust chief, at a news conference in Brussels in April 2016.
item.description: Regulators are set to impose a penalty of more than $1 billion and force the company to alter how it operates, according to people familiar with the case.
item.dc:creator: MARK SCOTT

item.title: Slack Is Said to Be in Talks to Raise $500 Million
item.media:description: Stewart Butterfield, chief executive of Slack, at the company’s office in San Francisco.
item.media:credit: Jason Henry for The New York Times
item.description: The office messaging company is not yet profitable, but new funding could raise its valuation to $5 billion as it faces rivals like Microsoft’s Teams.
item.dc:creator: KATIE BENNER

item.title: Jeff Bezos Wants Ideas for Philanthropy, So He Asked Twitter
item.media:description: Jeff Bezos, the founder and chief executive of Amazon, is worth more than $80 billion, according to Forbes. He sought ideas for helping the world in the short term.
item.description: The Amazon chief asked for tips where his money could be used in the “here and now,” unlike many of his business investments.
item.dc:creator: NICK WINGFIELD

item.title: Wheels: Envisioning the Car of the Future as a Living Room on Wheels
item.media:description: BMW’s show car at CES in Las Vegas, the annual consumer electronics show in Las Vegas.
item.description: As driverless cars develop, how we sit, inform and entertain ourselves are all up for grabs — and companies, designers and researchers are dreaming big.
item.dc:creator: ERIC A. TAUB

item.title: Facebook Will Use Artificial Intelligence to Find Extremist Posts
item.media:description: Facebook says the first use of its new artificial intelligence program will be to prevent the posting of gruesome content such as images from terrorist attacks.
item.media:credit: Patricia De Melo Moreira/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: Under pressure from governments to counter inappropriate content, the social media company will pair new technology with human moderators.
item.dc:creator: SHEERA FRENKEL
